facts.text: High Court revision arose from order dated July 6, 1957 of Second Additional Judge, City Civil Court, Hyderabad in O.S. No. 43/1 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the order dated July 6, 1957, of the Court of the Second Additional Judge, City Civil Court, Hyderabad Decan , made on the application under 0. 1, r. 10,  C. P. C. in Original Suit No. 43/1 of 1957.

facts.text: Plaintiff instituted suit on April 12, 1957 against third respondent, second son of Nizam of Hyderabad, referred to as the Prince.

anchor.surface_text: On April 12, 1957, the plaintiff-appellant in this Court- instituted the suit out of which this appeal arises against the third respondent who is the second son of His Exalted Highness the Nizam of Hyderabad, and who will, hereinafter, be referred to as the Prince.

facts.text: Plaintiff alleged marriage to Prince via Nikah on October 19, 1948 according to Shia Law by Shia Mujtahid.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint she alleged that she is the lawfully married wife of the Prince, the marriage ceremony  Nikah  having been solemnized in accordance with the Shia Law by a Shia Mujtahid on October 19, 1948.

facts.text: Marriage produced three daughters aged 8, 7, and 5 years.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff also averred that the issue of the marriage were three daughters aged 8, 7 and 5 years that the fact of the marriage was known to all persons acquainted with the Prince

facts.text: Prenuptial agreement for Rs. 2,000 per month as Kharch-e-pandan, payments stopped since January 1953.

anchor.surface_text: that there was a prenuptial agreement, whereby the Prince agreed to pay Rs. 2,000 per month to the plaintiff as Kharch-e-pandan that the Prince stopped the payment of the allowance aforesaid of Rs. 2,000 per month, since January, 1953,

facts.text: Plaintiff sought declaration as legally wedded wife and entitled to Rs. 2,000 per month Kharch-e-pandan.

anchor.surface_text: On these allegations, she asked for the following two declarations- That the plaintiff be declared to be the legally-wedded wife  Mankuha  of the defendant, That a decree be passed in favour of this plaintiff against the defendant declaring her to be entitled to receive from the defendant 1. G. Its. 2,000 per month as Kharch-e-pandan.

facts.text: Prince filed written statement on April 22, 1957 admitting entire claim of plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: Only ten days later, on April 22, 1957, the Prince filed his written statement, admitting the entire claim of the plaintiff for the two declarations aforesaid.

facts.text: On April 22, 1957, Sahebzadi Anwar Begum (Resp1) and her minor son Prince Shahainat Ali Khan (Resp2) applied under O.1 r.10 CPC to intervene.

anchor.surface_text: On that very date, an application under 0. 1, r. 10, of the Code of Civil Procedure, on behalf of  1  Saliebzadi Anwar Begum, and  2  Prince Shahainat Ali Khan, minor, under the Guardianship of his mother, the said Sahebzadi, was made. They are respondents I and 2 respectively in this Court.

facts.text: Resp1 claimed to be lawful wife of Prince, Resp2 his son by Resp1.

anchor.surface_text: The Sahebzadi, respondent 1, claimed to be the lawful and legally wedded wife of the Prince, and respondent 2, the son of the Prince by the first respondent.

facts.text: Interveners alleged collusion between plaintiff and Prince, suit to affect their rights in Prince's estate.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners on being joined as parties to the suit will be equally interested in denying the marriage of the plaintiff and her rights and status The peti- tioners have reasons to believe that the above suit is a result of companylusion. The object and motive of the plaintiff in instituting the above suit is to adversely affect the relationship of the petitioners and the defendant and also to deprive the rights and interests of the petitioners in the defendants estate.

facts.text: Prince stated he married plaintiff in October 1948 and first respondent in December 1952.

anchor.surface_text: He repeated his admission by saying that lie married the plaintiff in October, 1948, and the first respondent in December 1952.

facts.text: Trial court allowed intervention on July 6, 1957, adding Resp1 and Resp2 as defendants 2 and 3.

anchor.surface_text: On these allegations and companynter allegations, after hearing the parties, the trial companyrt, by its judgment and order dated July 6, 1957, allowed the application for intervention, and directed respondents 1 and 2 to be added as defendants.

facts.text: AP High Court dismissed revision petition on September 17, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff moved the High Court of Judicature of Andhra Pradesh, at Hyderabad, under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure, to revise the aforesaid order of the learned trial judge. The High Court, in a wellconsidered judgment, ... refused to interfere ... and dismissed the revisional application.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Against the judgment of the High Court, refusing to set aside the order passed by the learned trial judge, 1118 the plaintiff moved this Court and obtained special leave to appeal.

facts.text: Trial court observed possible collusion between plaintiff and defendant.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt, after discussing all the companytentions raised on behalf of the parties, observed that there were indications in the record of a possible companylusion between the plaintiff and the defendant

facts.text: Prince supported Muslim right to have four wives.

anchor.surface_text: He also supported the plaintiff in her denial of the allegation of companylusion ... by insisting upon his Muslim right of having four wives living at the same time.

facts.text: Barkat Ali, Shia Mujtahid, examined on April 27, 1957 supporting plaintiff's marriage claim.

anchor.surface_text: a few days after the filing of the written statement of the Prince, on April 27, Barkat Ali, the Mujtahid, who is alleged to have solemnized the marriage, was examined in companyrt, and he gave his statement on oath in support of the plaintiffs claim.

facts.text: Supreme Court majority dismissed appeal, upheld addition of parties.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, accordingly, 1133 dismissed.

facts.text: Imam J dissented, would allow appeal and set aside orders adding parties.

anchor.surface_text: I would, accordingly, allow the appeal as both the companyrts below were in error ... and would set aside the orders of the companyrts below.

facts.text: Prince admitted Resp1 married in Dec 1952, knew of prior three daughters by plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: He added further that when he married the first respondent, he had already three daughters by the plaintiff, which fact was known to the first respondent at the time of her marriage with him.

arguments.claim: S43 SRA narrower/wider than res judicata; binds privies in blood for status

anchor.surface_text: The rule laid down in s. 43 of the Specific Relief Act is not exactly a rule of res judicata. It is narrower in one sense and wider in another...
